author: David Steinberg / For The Journal
title: Daring and independent, these four women left their marks on the Southwest
text:
Georgia O’Keeffe and Mabel Dodge Luhan are usually the independent women we think of who quit the East Coast to make new homes in New Mexico in the first half of the 20th century.
Lesley Poling-Kempes discusses, signs “Ladies of the Canyons” at 3 today at Page One, Mountain Run Shopping Center, Eubank and Juan Tabo NE; at 4 p.m. Oct. 18 at SOMOS, 233 Paseo del Pueblo Sur, Taos; at 7 p.m. Oct. 22 at Mesa Public Library, 2400 Central Ave., Los Alamos; at 3 p.m. Nov. 7 Ghost Ranch Conference Center, Abiquiú; and at noon Dec. 2 at the Fray Angelico Chavez History Library’s Meem Community Room, downtown Santa Fe.
Lesser known were four educated, independent, single women adventurers who came to the Southwest – three from the East – in the first decades of the century. Before O’Keeffe and Luhan.
The four – Natalie Curtis, Carol Stanley, Alice Klauber and Mary Cabot Wheelwright – are the main subjects of Lesley Poling-Kempes’ new book “Ladies of the Canyons.”
Reading the book is a rewarding experience. It illuminates the previously neglected contributions of these women within multiple historical contexts.
It sheds light on their connections to regional, nationally and internationally known figures in the arts, in anthropology and in politics of that period. It shows each of them as “The New Woman” who was breaking free of Victorian America’s tethers on single women.
Curtis, a concert pianist and composer, left the comfort of her family’s New York City home to head to West in search of a healthier climate. She ended up recording the songs of the Hopi and other tribes.
By experience, Curtis was an ethnologist and ethnomusicologist who quietly championed the preservation of their culture.
By interest, she fought federal policies on boarding Indian children; she told Teddy Roosevelt, a family friend, about injustices against Indians.
“Ladies of the Canyons – A League of Extraordinary Women and Their Adventures in the American Southwest” by Lesley Poling-Kempes
University of Arizona Press, 24.95, 373 pp. Stanley left her home near Boston to eventually run dude ranches in northern New Mexico. She founded Ghost Ranch.
Klauber, from California, was an unassuming artist who often painted in Santa Fe. She became a patron of the arts in San Diego, Calif.
Wheelwright left her Boston Brahmin life, to come to the Southwest. She recorded Navajo chants, myths and ceremonies that led to her founding the Museum of Navajo Ceremonial Art (renamed the Wheelwright Museum of the American Indian) in Santa Fe.
Poling-Kempes’ book came out of her research on a book about Ghost Ranch.
“There was Carol Stanley, who built the first cottages, the headquarters at Ghost Ranch and lived alone there in 1931,” she said. “I thought, ‘Why didn’t we talk about her? Why didn’t we know about her?'”
The author began digging into diaries and journals and later other archival material.
“So I knew Wheelwright was somehow involved with Carol but I didn’t know how. The same with Alice Klauber. I had never heard of her. She was also connected with Natalie Curtis,” Poling-Kempes said.
“I knew there was a great story about these women. I was never certain how interesting their stories would be. There was more to their stories than I thought. It was wonderful. Their lives reached out to other people’s lives.”
The more she pursued, the more substance she found in the stories of these women’s intertwined lives rooted in northern New Mexico.
